articles.headline: State Farm Told to Pay Gulf Claim
articles.snippet: The $2.5 million penalty against State Farm throws into question settlement talks intended to resolve hundreds of lawsuits filed after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: The $2.5 million penalty against State Farm throws into question settlement talks intended to resolve hundreds of lawsuits filed after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal jury ordered State Farm insurance yesterday to pay a $2.5 million penalty for refusing to cover damages to a Mississippi couple’s house that was destroyed in Hurricane Katrina, throwing into question settlement talks intended to resolve hundreds of lawsuits filed after the 2005 storm.

articles.headline: Iraq Dominates World Politics, Not Markets
articles.snippet: Investors act as if they believe that Iraq will be like Vietnam in a very important way: In the long run, it will have little real significance for the world economy.
articles.abstract: Investors act as if they believe that Iraq will be like Vietnam in a very important way: In the long run, it will have little real significance for the world economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Washington squares off over Iraq, with President Bush warning of disaster if the United States withdraws and Democrats saying that another 20,000 troops will not reverse what has gone wrong, two questions come to mind:

articles.headline: G.I.’s in Iraq Raid Iranians’ Offices
articles.snippet: U.S. troops raided an Iranian diplomatic office and detained as many as six of the Iranians working inside.
articles.abstract: U.S. troops raided an Iranian diplomatic office and detained as many as six of the Iranians working inside.
articles.lead_paragraph: ERBIL, Iraq, Jan. 11  American troops backed by attack helicopters and armored vehicles raided an Iranian diplomatic office in the dead of night early Thursday and detained as many as six of the Iranians working inside.

articles.headline: Hire by the Contract Now, Risk a Big Regret Later
articles.snippet: Employment contracts have been blamed for virtually guaranteeing huge payouts even when an executive fails.
articles.abstract: Employment contracts have been blamed for virtually guaranteeing huge payouts even when an executive fails.
articles.lead_paragraph: The new heads of Exxon Mobil, PepsiCo and Pfizer don’t have one. Nor do the chief executives at Citigroup, General Electric and Procter & Gamble. And some corporate governance experts say shareholders are better off as a result.

articles.headline: Duke Accuser Contradicts Herself
articles.snippet: The woman said two players, not three, attacked her in the bathroom at a lacrosse team party in March.
articles.abstract: The woman said two players, not three, attacked her in the bathroom at a lacrosse team party in March.
articles.lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.C., Jan. 11 — In an interview last month with a district attorney’s investigator, the woman who has accused three Duke lacrosse players of sexual assault contradicted critical evidence and parts of her earlier accounts, dealing a new blow to a faltering case.

articles.headline: An Updraft for the Airlines
articles.snippet: The chief of US Airways, with a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta, has helped make the industry feel better about itself again.
articles.abstract: The chief of US Airways, with a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta, has helped make the industry feel better about itself again.
articles.lead_paragraph: TEMPE, Ariz. — A good mood can be infectious, and W. Douglas Parker, chief executive of US Airways, with a sunny disposition and a $10.5 billion takeover proposal for Delta Air Lines, has helped make the airline industry feel better about itself again.

articles.headline: Agents Say Fast Audits Hurt I.R.S.
articles.snippet: I.R.S. agents are being pushed to prematurely close audits of big companies, a policy costing the government billions.
articles.abstract: I.R.S. agents are being pushed to prematurely close audits of big companies, a policy costing the government billions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Top officials at the Internal Revenue Service are pushing agents to prematurely close audits of big companies with agreements to have them pay only a fraction of the additional taxes that could be collected, according to dozens of I.R.S. employees who say that the policy is costing the government billions of dollars a year.
